context:
The George Brown College's Academic Upgrading (A751) program is a free program funded by the Employment Ontario branch of the Ministry of Labour, Training and Skills Development (MLTSD). As an enrolled student, you will have access to advising services (academic advising and career counselling) and may be eligible for a transportation allowance. The program delivery is flexible with both full-time and part-time study options available, running year-round with classes starting every seven weeks. You will create an individualized learning plan to support your life, academic and career goals, and the length of your program will vary based on your initial academic assessment, specific goals, and individual progress. Prior to starting this program, you will be required to complete a reading and writing assessment to determine your literacy levels and program eligibility.

Communications courses offered include Foundations, ACE (Academic and Career Entrance, grade 12C equivalent course for college admission purposes), Pre-ACE, and Personal and Professional Exploration (ACE level course designed to solidify student plans for college and careers). Math courses offered include ACE Business Math (grade 12C equivalent course for college admission purposes), ACE Apprenticeship Math (grade 12C equivalent course for college or Apprenticeship admission purposes), and ACE Technology Math (grade 12C equivalent course for college admission purposes). Science courses offered are physics, chemistry, and biology (only at the ACE level for college admission purposes).

By completing courses in this program, you can earn Academic and Career Entrance (ACE), grade 12 “C” equivalent credits, to apply for any program offered at an Ontario Community College. Each program intake begins with a one-day online orientation session. Students may be eligible to receive a transportation subsidy, a netbook, and/or monthly Internet device.
question: , Which course is a grade 12C equivalent course for college admission purposes in Communications?

context:
Program Offered: The graduate demonstrates skills in statistics and data analysis with a focus on analytics. Specific courses mentioned include STAT 4001 and STAT 4003. The program covers topics such as extracting, transforming and loading data, data warehousing, model development, business intelligence tools usage, communication of results, statistical techniques application to Big Data, digital information analysis, and ethics in data use for business decision-making.

Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate will be able to efficiently support problem-solving and decision-making through data manipulation; warehouse and mine data for business decision-making purposes; develop classification and predictive models using operational and marketing data; effectively communicate analytics results using various methods; apply statistical techniques to Big Data; analyze and interpret digital information for an organization; and apply business ethics and corporate social responsibility principles in the use of data.

Costs: The tuition and fees for domestic students for the first two semesters is $4,379.00*. Financial assistance is available through OSAP for eligible applicants.

Admission Requirements: Applicants need a college advanced diploma (three-year), bachelor's degree, or relevant work experience with a resume and references. English language proficiency tests are required for some international applicants. College credits may be transferable for exemptions. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.

*Note: Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.

The text mentions a program focused on codes and construction law, with an emphasis on teamwork in a project-based learning environment. Students enrolling in January are required to complete semester 2 in the summer (May to August) of the same year to continue into semester 3 in the fall.

Graduates find employment in various areas of the Architectural, Engineering and Construction (AEC) industry, including architectural and construction industries, technical sales representatives and manufacturing technicians for product manufacturers and building material suppliers, and government building departments. Career options for graduates include, but are not limited to, project coordinator, technical representative for building/equipment suppliers, production of computer-aided technical drawings and modelling, developer, property manager, technician with builders/developers, and customer service agent with builders/developers.

This program shares the first four semesters with the three-year Architectural Technology program (T109), allowing graduates to transfer with advanced standing into the third year of that program. The first two semesters are also shared with the three-year Interior Design Technology program (T170), allowing graduates to transfer with advanced standing into the second year of that program. Pathways to the Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program are also available from the three-year Architectural Technology program.

The required courses for semester 1 include ARCH 1005: Architectural Technology & Studio 1, ARCH 1014: Canadian Industry Practices, ARCH 1048: Structural Systems 1, ARCH 1050: Visual Communications 1, ARCH 1060: Design Fundamentals, CADE 1012: CAD Drawing 1, COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts, and MATH 1139: Mathematics for Arch/IDT 1.

   - Bachelor of Science – Architectural Major (Post-Diploma) Program at Athabasca University, Alberta, Canada.

   - Master of Architecture Degree with Boston Architectural College (BAC) in Boston, Massachusetts, USA.

context:
The George Brown College offers a flexible applied degree program in Trades Business Management. The program includes conducting research for strategic and operational decisions, deploying strategic planning techniques, applying project and risk management principles, identifying opportunities and challenges, applying management principles, planning marketing strategies, complying with laws and regulations, using software and technologies, interpreting financial information, and contributing to the community through cultural diversity, social responsibility, economic commitment, and environmental stewardship.

Tuition and fees vary based on the courses enrolled in at any given time and are subject to change without notice. Domestic tuition and additional costs information can be obtained by contacting the business department at business@georgebrown.ca. Books and additional supplies are not included in tuition fees and must be purchased separately. OSAP eligibility for this program has yet to be reviewed by the Ministry.

The admission requirements include a post-secondary transcript and a departmental review. Eligible professions for this degree include Carpenter, Drywall Finisher and Plasterer, Gasfitter – Class A, Gasfiter – Class B, Industrial Mechanic (Millwright), Oil Heat System Technician, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Mechanic, and Plumber. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions. George Brown has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer this applied degree for a seven-year term starting from December 21, 2020.

context:
The Behavioural Science Technician program offered at George Brown College is a two-year Ontario College diploma program with the code C146. Graduates of this program are eligible to enter the bridging pathway into the third year of the Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis degree program (S303). International students who have completed this program can apply to the S303 Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (Year 3 Bridge) program stream.

Career options for Behavioural Science Technician graduates include being an instructor therapist, behaviour therapist, behaviour technician, behaviour consultant, resource facilitator, or working in residential facilities, vocational agencies, or other specialized agencies.

The first semester courses for this program include Behavioural Theory (BST 1003), Behaviour Theory and Practice: Introduction to ABA (BST 1007), Lifespan Development (BST 1021), Introduction to Psychology (BST 1022), Strategies for Student Success (BST 1028), College Communication (COMM 1000 or COMM 2000), and a General Education Elective.

The second semester courses are Developmental Disabilities in Ontario: Policy and Process (BST 1029), Behaviour Theory and Practice: Behavioural Assessment (BST 1030), Interpersonal and Group Skills (BST 1031), Ethics and Professionalism (BST 1032), and Field Seminar I (BST 2009).

For more information about the degree pathway or international student applications, please contact Program Co-ordinator Don Togade at Don.Togade@georgebrown.ca. Graduates interested in working in a long-term care facility should consider applying to the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care postgraduate certificate (S417).

question: What is the name of this program?

context:
The Behavioural Science Technician program at the college focuses on teaching behavioural principles, assessment and intervention procedures, and professional skills for employment in various workplaces such as autism, mental health, gerontology, acquired brain injury, organizational behaviour management, sport, etc. This program does not teach counselling or "talk therapy" skills. The themes studied in this program include behavioural theory, behavioural assessment, behavioural acquisition and reduction strategies, scientific method, ethics and professionalism, and general education with a practical application in the field. Students can find employment opportunities as behaviour science technicians upon completion of the program. For those with a bachelor's degree in psychology or related discipline, an accelerated delivery of this program leading to a diploma is offered in less than one year.

Associations related to this field of study include the Association of Behaviour Analysis International, The Ontario Association for Behaviour Analysis, Inc., and Association of Professional Behavior Analysts. Students can also visit the Behavior Analyst Certification Board for more information on this field of study.

The field placement component of the program provides students with the opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge in a real-world environment. Each field experience builds upon the previous one and provides exposure to various work environments. Field placements are unpaid and completed on a full-time basis, and George Brown Faculty works with students and community partners to secure these placements. Field education may require travel due to the availability of suitable placements within the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), potentially extending as far east as Oshawa and as far west as an undisclosed location.

No specific years, numbers, emails, or names were provided in the text.

The George Brown College in Toronto offers a Blockchain Development program that lasts for three semesters. The curriculum focuses on the design and deployment of decentralized applications using blockchain technology. Students will learn skills such as smart contracts design, full stack development, integration of blockchain architecture, security practices, and more.

The program is delivered in a full-time executive format requiring approximately 20 hours of study each week over a 26-week duration. In the third semester, students have the option to engage in a Co-op placement or work-integrated learning experience.

The technology requirements for the program include a personal computer with a minimum of 8 GB RAM (16 GB recommended), 256 GB SSD Hard Drive (500+ GB is optimal), Quad-core i5/i7 2.4GHz or better, and the ability to run Ubuntu 20.04 (can be on a virtual machine). Students also need a webcam.

Graduates of this program may apply for positions such as blockchain engineer, blockchain developer, blockchain architect, smart contract developer, dApp developer, blockchain solution analyst, or blockchain consultant. Career options include the blockchain industry to support Toronto as a leading blockchain city.

The School of Construction Management at George Brown College recommends that students own or purchase a laptop with the following specifications:

- Operating system: Windows 10 Home 64-bit English
- Processor: 9th Generation Intel® Core™ i7-9750H (12MB Cache, up to 4.5 GHz, 6 cores)
- Memory (RAM): 16GB (2x8GB DDR4 2666MHz)
- Disk space: 256GB M.2 PCIe NVMe Solid State Drive (Boot) + 1TB 5400 rpm 2.5" SATA Hard Drive (Storage)
- Display card: NVIDIA® GeForce RTX™ 2060 6GB GDDR6
- Connectivity: 802.11ac WiFi and Bluetooth, 2 x 2
- Ports: 1x HDMI 2.0; 3x SuperSpeed USB 3.1 Gen 1 Type-A including 1x with PowerShare; 1x 2-in-1 SD / MicroMedia Card slot; 1x Wedge lock slot
- Screen size: minimum 15.6 inch FHD(1920 x 1080) 300nits IPS Anti-Glare LED backlit display with 144Hz refresh rate

context:
This program is a two-year construction technology diploma offered at George Brown College in Ontario, Canada. The program covers practical applications in residential construction and renovations, millwork, demolition, framing, finishes, drywall installation and finishing, site management, cabinetry, stair construction, building code, basic electrical systems, HVAC systems, and plumbing systems.

Business skills taught include business management, marketing, client relations, project management, site management, scheduling, controlling, estimating and bookkeeping, budgeting and financial management, and inspections. Students will also learn how to use computer software and technology commonly used in the construction industry.

The program consists of four semesters. Semester 1 includes courses such as Residential Construction Lab 1, Plan Interpretation 1, History of Architecture, Communicating Across Contexts, Mathematics for Building Technologies 1, and Construction Safety & Rig. Students are required to complete two semesters of field placement as part of the program.

Graduates may be eligible for direct entry into the third year of George Brown College's Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program with bridge courses required. For more information, see the Diploma to Degree page on the college website.

Students who start the program in the Winter term will take first and second semester courses in alternatively delivered formats. The program is unique in Ontario.
question: , How many semesters does the program consist of?

context:
The Centre for Business programs at George Brown College are accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP). There are 14 Centre for Business diploma, advanced diploma, and degree programs that have been accredited globally. Two colleges in Ontario have earned ACBSP accreditation, with George Brown being one of them.

Centre for Business students are required to bring their own laptops due to the college's Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative. The Library Learning Commons offers open access computers and equipment that can be borrowed on a short-term basis.

Field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients are available at the Centre for Business. Graduates of this program are prepared for careers in various business sectors, including manufacturing, merchandising, service organizations, federal, provincial and municipal government offices, banks and other financial institutions. Career options include roles as accounts analyst, accounts payable and receivable clerk, bookkeeper, customer service representative.

The two-year diploma in Business Administration – Accounting has a pathway to the three-year advanced diploma B107 / B157. Graduates of this program may be eligible to transfer into the Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program based on completion of the entire program, individual courses, and/or program GPA. Eligibility assessment is handled by Katherine Friesen, kfriesen@georgebrown.ca; Francis Taylor, francis.taylor@georgebrown.ca; Kelly Jung, kelly.jung@georgebrown.ca. For more information on additional future study options, see the transfer guide.

Graduates of this program may wish to obtain various designations.

The two-year diploma in question is an approved program through FP Canada for pursuing the QAFP™ examination. It has a direct pathway to the B302 Honours Bachelor of Commerce degree program at George Brown College, also approved through FP Canada for the CFP® designation. The diploma is called "B133" and individuals with a Program GPA of 3.0 or higher may transfer into Semester 5 of B302 to complete their degree. The text also mentions that effective April 1, 2022, individuals wishing to pursue the CFP® certification require a minimum bachelor’s degree, while those seeking QAFP™ certification require a minimum 2-year college diploma.

Additional certifications or credentials that graduates of this program may pursue include the Canadian Securities Course (CSC) through the Canadian Securities Institute and the Life License Qualification Program (LLQP) through Oliver’s Learning or another approved provider. To graduate from the college, students are required to complete 34 courses in total. Three of these courses must be General Education Electives chosen from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI).

Students may be required to take certain prerequisite courses before progressing to others, such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation). These courses do not count towards the 34 courses required for graduation and students will be charged extra for them.

Students must make up any failed or dropped courses before being eligible to graduate. Some making-up courses can be taken during the day, while others are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. Students should check with the business office staff to ensure that continuing education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program and to inquire about any special timetable requirements they may have. Some courses may not be offered in every semester.

context:
The George Brown College offers a Human Resources advanced diploma (B144) program which requires completion of 36 courses: 29 mandatory courses, 4 Business Electives, and 3 General Education Electives. Students with an overall grade point average of 3.0 or higher from this program are eligible for block transfer admission into semester 5 of the Human Resources Strategy and Technology degree program at Seneca College.

Students may be required to take additional courses such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses, but these do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation and will incur an extra charge.

Students must complete at least 3 General Education courses chosen from at least 2 categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation. Some makeup courses may be offered in the evening through Continuing Education, but students should check with the business office staff for equivalence to full-time program courses and availability in each semester.

Additional information on the Certified Training and Development Professional (CTDP) designation offered through The Institute for Performance and Learning can be found at performanceandlearning.ca/page/GettingCertified. Students with a grade point average of 3.0 or higher from the Business Administration – Human Resources advanced diploma are eligible for block transfer admission into semester 5 of the Human Resources Strategy and Technology degree program at Seneca College. More information on future study options can be found in the transfer guide.

context:
The George Brown College offers a program related to international business where students will learn about documents and procedures supporting global supply chains, statutory and regulatory compliance, international payment instruments and options, foreign exchange strategies, and human resource strategies in an international operation. The college has partnered with FITT (Forum for International Trade Training) to provide the FITTskills program and offer the Certified International Trade Professional (CITP) designation.

The Centre for Business programs at George Brown College have earned accreditation from the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), making it one of only two colleges in Ontario with this recognition. Students in this program are required to bring their own laptops as part of a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative. The college offers open access computers and equipment that can be borrowed at the Library Learning Commons for short-term use.

Programs offered by George Brown College's School of Management have earned international recognition from ACBSP, with 14 diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs accredited globally in Accounting & Finance, HR, Management, and Marketing. The requirements for each designation/certification are set by the granting body, FITT, and students must follow their process to qualify.

George Brown College's partnership with FITT allows students to earn the CITP designation, a professional certification in international trade. FITT is an international trade training and certification body that sets standards and designs training programs for this designation. Students can contact the Centre for Business at business@georgebrown.ca for more information.

context:
To graduate from the college, students must complete three General Education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation.

Students can make up these classes during the day, and some are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. It is important for students to check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program. Some courses may not be offered in every semester, and the college staff can assist students with any special timetable requirements they may have.

The following is a list of courses offered in each semester:

- ACCT 1036: Principles of Accounting (NONE)
- BUS 1040: Project Management (NONE)

- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I

- ECON 1032: Macroeconomics (NONE)
- MGMT 4009: Operations Management

- STAT 1012: Business Statistics (MATH 1095 required)
- CMMK 1087: Human Skills (NONE)
- BUS 1000: Work Experience Prep Course (* this course only applies to students taking the Work Experience Option (B156), COMM 1007 & 3.0 GPA required)
- Select One General Education Elective

Semester 4:
- ACCT 2031: Managerial Accounting (ACCT 1036 required)

Students must complete courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). They are also required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation. Students can make up these classes during the day, and some are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. It is important for students to check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program. context: The George Brown College offers a program with the code B156, which requires completion of 37 courses: 31 mandatory courses, 3 Business Electives, and 3 General Education Electives. Students also need to complete 2 Work Experience Terms, which can be in the form of co-op, internship, simulation, consulting, or research projects. International students are not eligible for optional co-op arrangements. The college provides field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients through the Centre for Business. George Brown College is a Global Registered Education Provider with the Project Management Institute (PMI) and prepares students to apply for either the Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM) or Project Management Professional (PMP) certification from PMI. Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses but these do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation. Students are advised to speak to the Business Office staff for assistance if needed.

question: What is the name of this business administration program?

context:
The George Brown College Business Administration program offers students the opportunity to complete two semesters of work experience as part of their graduation requirements. This work experience can be in the form of a co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid) position. International students are not eligible for optional co-op arrangements. The college also provides field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients. Students can contact the Centre for Business at business@georgebrown.ca for more information.

In total, students must complete 38 courses to graduate from the B162 program, including 35 mandatory courses, 3 General Education Electives, and 2 Work Experience terms. Depending on the results of placement tests, students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses. However, these courses do not count toward the 37 courses required for graduation and will result in additional charges.

Additionally, students of the Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Diploma can apply for a fast-track into the CSCMP Designation program through George Brown College's partnership with SCMAO. This designation is Canada's leading credential for supply chain professionals looking to advance their careers. More information on this opportunity can be found by learning more at the Centre for Business.

The Child and Youth Care (Accelerated) program at George Brown College is an Ontario College Advanced Diploma program. The duration of the program is 12 consecutive months and it is offered on a full-time basis starting in May each year. The program is designed to teach students to work effectively with at-risk children, youth, and families who are experiencing developmental, mental health, emotional, and behavioural difficulties.

The domestic tuition fee for this program is $3,661.00 and the international tuition fee is $17,318.00. The program is delivered in a hybrid format during the fall 2023 semester (Semester 5) and "Other" format during the winter 2024 semester (Semester 6). It is located at the St. James Campus. The program includes experiential learning through an unpaid field placement.

The program has earned national accreditation from the Child and Youth Care Educational Accreditation Board of Canada, making it the first of its kind in the Greater Toronto and Hamilton area and the third in Canada to do so.

context:
The George Brown College offers a College Vocational (A101) program through its partnership with PTP Adult Learning & Employment Programs. This program helps students develop job-readiness skills and supports individual career exploration to find appropriate employment. Students participate in employment related workshops delivered by PTP and have the opportunity for workplace experience that can lead to paid employment upon graduation.

The program is a two-semester, in-person delivery designed for high school graduates with an Ontario Secondary School Certificate (OSSC) or Diploma (OSSD) who have workplace or college credits. The course content includes self-exploration and career planning, communication and math skills training, digital skills training, and intrapersonal and interpersonal skills enhancement.

Upon completion of the College Vocational (A101) program at George Brown, graduates can take specialized job training programs, enroll in additional college programs, or continue to work with PTP employment counsellors and job developers to find meaningful paid employment.

Required courses for Semester 1 include LIFE 1015: Personal and Professional Dynamics I, COMM 1158: Communications and Mathematics Skills and Strategies I, PREP 1016: Transitions to Work, and PREP 1020: Digital Skills for Life and Work I. Semester 2 courses include LIFE 1016: Personal and Professional Dynamics II, COMM 1159: Communications and Mathematics Skills and Strategies II, PREP 1029: Pathways to Work, and PREP 1030: Digital Skills for Life and Work II. Students also complete a Work-Integrated Learning Practicum (PREP 1035).

Program learning outcomes include applying key information processing skills to employment and academic contexts, applying workplace conventions and practices, producing a career pathway plan with associated artifacts, and using essential literacies such as communication, numeracy, digital, media.

context: The George Brown College's Community Worker (Accelerated) program is a fast-track, three semester long program focused on social justice and human rights, suitable for students with an existing diploma or degree. Students will learn to work with urban communities on issues such as poverty, housing, food justice, immigration and settlement. The program combines classroom instruction with supervised field placements and offers opportunities to develop skills in anti-oppressive practice, critical analysis, group facilitation, counselling, conflict mediation, community organizing, activism and advocacy, among others. The program boasts strong ties with over 350 agencies across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) and beyond. Students who apply to the 2023/24 intake will start in May 2024. To begin studies in May 2023, applicants should apply to the 2022/23 academic year instead. An additional designation of RSSW (Registered Social Service Worker) can be obtained with extra fees.

context:
This text provides information about the Community Worker program offered by the college and the career opportunities and educational pathways for graduates. The following facts can be extracted from the text:

* The Community Worker program is an approved education program by the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers (OCSWSSW).
* Graduates of this program may apply to receive the additional designation of RSSW (Registered Social Service Worker), with extra fees applying.
* Career options for Community Worker graduates include: shelter supervisors, international development workers, immigration and refugee settlement, community development, health and community advocacy in food justice, Indigenous rights, and climate justice.
* Graduates may apply for advanced entry into other programs such as: Community Development B.A. at Algoma University, Community Development B.A. at Humber College, Policing & Community Well-Being (B.A) at Trent University, Professional Communications B.A. and Justice Studies B.A. at Royal Roads University, Social Work B.A. programs at Toronto Metropolitan University, and York University.
* Required courses for the first semester include: CWRK 1001 - Introduction to Community Work, CWRK 1005 - Human Rights in Community Work Practice, and CWRK 1008 - Interpersonal Communication. Additionally, CWRK 1020 is mentioned but not included in the list of required courses.
* Students are encouraged to work with the field education coordinator to identify placement opportunities that do not require the vulnerable sector check. They may also apply for Suppression and Destruction of Record or Record Suspension at their specific regional police services.

The text discusses an approved education program for Community Workers offered by a college with strong ties to over 350 agencies across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA). graduates of this program may apply to receive the additional designation of RSSW (Registered Social Service Worker), and there are extra fees for this designation.

The Community Worker Program features include a long-standing relationship with Anishnawbe Health Toronto (AHT), where graduates of AHT’s Community Health Worker Training Program can gain direct entry into the second year of the Community Worker program. The annual Tommy Douglas Institute is also mentioned, which brings participants together to explore community, education and social justice in the twenty-first century.

The role of a Community Worker includes working with individuals and communities at all levels towards positive social change, and being committed to inclusion, equality, diversity, and human dignity. The program teaches a variety of important skills, such as anti-oppressive and intercultural practice, critical analysis, group facilitation, community organizing, advocacy, and policy analysis.

The Community Worker Program structure includes classroom instruction and two supervised field placements, with theory, analysis, and practice presented through popular education and learner-centered approaches. The program is divided into four core areas: community work theory and practice, social and political analysis, group skills and counselling, and field placement and seminar.

The faculty are experienced educators who come from backgrounds in local, national, and global activism. No specific factual information such as names, emails, or numbers were mentioned in the text.

context: The George Brown College offers a three-year (six-semester) Computer Programmer Analyst program. The first two years focus on software application development and testing, while the final year develops advanced technical abilities and communication skills. Students are involved in project-based and experiential learning. In the third year, students are introduced to AI and Machine-Learning strategies and development, as well as mobile application development using the latest mobile devices. The program requirements include a personal computer with specifications of at least 16 GB RAM, 256 GB SSD Hard Drive, Quad-core i7 2.4GHz processor, 2GB Video Ram (4GB recommended), and a Webcam. Graduates may find career opportunities in areas such as database administration, systems analysis and design, consulting, application design and development, web application design and development, data architect (AI/Machine Learning), full-stack developer, and mobile application developer. Opportunities for systems development exist for corporate clients and smaller contract companies. If you enrol in January, you must complete semester 2 in the summer, May to August, of the same year. The program is subject to ongoing improvements which may result in course changes made in consultation with the Program Advisory Committee.

context:
The Construction Craft Worker Program is a free, 18-week long program starting in April with full-time delivery. It includes classroom and construction lab instruction and approximately 30 to 35 hours of class and construction lab time per week. The program provides 160 hours of work placement and workshops. Graduates will receive an Ontario College Certificate and have access to tutoring and support from program coaches.

Construction Craft Worker graduates will be qualified for entry-level jobs in the construction industry, such as construction labourer, carpentry helper, masonry helper, cement-finishing helper, demolition worker, and many other areas in the building trades. The required courses include BLDG 1058: Plans, Specifications and Calculations; BLDG 1059: Construction Site Safety, Tools and Equipment; BLDG 1060: Concrete Work, Scaffolding and Hoisting; BLDG 1061: Construction Site Works; BLDG 1062: Industry Practicum; COUN 1033: Field Integration; FAID 1003: Standard First Aid; MATH 1100: Foundation Math for Building Technologies; and MATH 1109: Mathematics for Building Technologies. WELD 1005: Metal Cutting is also a part of the program.

The graduate will be able to select, use, and operate safely tools and equipment used by construction craft workers and carpenters, masons, bricklayers, and other construction-related trades. They will also be able to select and apply appropriate material types for use in new residential/commercial construction and renovation. Graduates will interpret and apply relevant information in the Ontario Building Code and Occupational Health and Safety Act regulations for Construction Projects (CSAO) as they relate to construction craft worker duties and the construction industry in general. They will identify unsafe conditions and take appropriate action on a job site, interpret and visualize a finished project from an orthographical projected drawing, apply construction processes to residential/commercial construction and common types of renovations, and solve construction-related problems using appropriate techniques in a variety of construction situations.

The George Brown College's Admissions Department recognizes the Continuing Education ESL Pathway program as the English Language requirement for any full-time (without co-op) Ontario College Certificate, Diploma, or Postgraduate Certificate program at George Brown College. This pathway is only valid within George Brown College and does not apply to programs with a co-op component.

The following mandatory courses need to be completed by Con Ed graduates to meet the minimum English language admission requirement:

1. ESL 9068 - ESL IIIB Advanced ($382.00)

3. ESL 9069 - Advanced Essay Writing ($316.00)
4. ESL 9078 - Academic Preparation for College/University Studies or ESL 9077 - IELTS Exam Preparation ($284.00)

Graduates of the Continuing Education ESL Pathway to George Brown College Certificates and Diplomas program will be considered and ranked among other applicants for their chosen programs, and they may need to fulfill any other academic requirements specific to those programs (e.g., math, science).

context:
The Cook Apprenticeship program at George Brown College offers in-school training at two levels (H601 and H607). Level I focuses on fundamental culinary skills and management practices, while Level II develops advanced culinary skills and leadership abilities. Both levels include on-the-job training under the sponsorship of a registered employer for earning the official Red Seal certification as a cook from the Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD) in Ontario.

Required courses for the Cook Apprenticeship program include:
- H601 COOK APPRENTICESHIP – BASIC: HOSF 6161 (Sanitation, Safety and Equipment), HOSF 6143 (Basic Nutrition), HOSF 6123 (Business Development – Basic), HOSF 6124 (Kitchen Management – Basic), HOSF 6125 (Food Theory – Basic), HOSF 6126 (Culinary Techniques – Basic), and HOSF 6127 (Bake Theory).
- H607 COOK APPRENTICESHIP – ADVANCED: HOSF 6133 (Business).

Graduates of the Cook Apprenticeship program can pursue careers in various industries such as restaurants, hotel dining rooms, cafés, hospitals, clubs and resorts, spas, and catering companies.

context:
The Culinary Management (Integrated Learning) program is a four-semester diploma program offered at George Brown College. In the first semester, students learn fundamental culinary skills and industry employability skills. In the second semester, they develop more advanced culinary skills and expand their food, wine, and culinary culture knowledge.

In the third semester, students gain industry experience by working in residency at either The Chefs’ House or The Café, along with online theory-based courses. In the fourth semement, students complete a 14-week industry residency at leading culinary and hospitality industry partners, concurrently attending online theory-based courses.

The program is ideal for self-motivated individuals looking to enhance their employability prospects upon graduation. The schedule for this program operates from Monday to Friday, with classes starting as early as 7 a.m. and ending as late as 10 p.m. Students have the opportunity to explore industry work experience opportunities outside of formal placements, which can be added to their resumé.

Students will attend residencies at The Chefs’ House or The Café in the third semester and complete a 14-week industry residency at industry partners in the fourth semester.

Extracted Information:

1. The program is developed in collaboration with the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH).
2. It is a free, two-semester, full-time program that starts in September.
3. The program includes classroom and kitchen lab instruction with approximately 30 to 35 hours per week class and kitchen lab time.
4. There are 150 hours of work placement and workshops.
5. Tutoring and support are available from program coaches.
6. Students graduate with an Ontario College Certificate.
7. Career options for graduates include entry-level food preparation jobs in commercial food service, cafeterias, fast food outlets, restaurants, and catering operations.
8. Required courses for Semester 1 include HOSF 1233: Baking Pastry and Theory – Basic, HOSF 1002: Baking and Pastry for Cooks, HOSF 1202: Culinary Foundations, HOSF 1029: Theory of Food I, HOSF 1145: Sanitation, HOSF 1237: Field Integration/Workshops I, MATH 1000: Mathematics Foundations for Hospitality, and HOSF 1255: Nutrition Fundamentals from a Culinary Perspective.
9. Required courses for Semester 2 include HOSF 1185: Fundamentals of Butchery, HOSF 1203: Culinary Essentials, HOSF 1241: Field Integration/Workshops II, HOSF 1242: Baking Techniques II, HOST 1005: Food Beverage and Labour Cost Control, HOSF 1244: Industry Practicum, MATH 1102: Math for Hospitality, and HOSF 1184: Café Production.
10. Students will have the ability to provide fundamental culinary preparation and presentation for a variety of food service environments using a range of classical and contemporary techniques.
11. Students will be able to apply basic food and bake science to food.

context:
The cyber security program at this college lasts for a full-time duration and is delivered in a blended format with both face-to-face sessions and online delivery. In the first semester, students learn the fundamentals of cyber security and the differences between it and hacking, focusing on primary attack surfaces, methods for compromising them, and vulnerability mitigation.

In the third semester, advanced techniques in ethical hacking and incident response are covered, and a capstone group project offers an opportunity to showcase skills in digital forensics and incident response management, ethical hacking and malware analysis, security training delivery, cryptography application, and other non-technical skills such as analytical thinking, communication, project management, and interpersonal skills.

The program prepares students to help defend organizations against various cyber threats including malware, network attacks, and data compromise. Students will have the ability to monitor, assess, and evaluate security risks and threats, develop contingency planning, and create policies and procedures for mitigating risks.

The full-time program requires learners to attend classes mostly in late afternoons and evenings during the week and all day Saturday. Students need a personal laptop with 8GB RAM (16GB recommended), support for virtualization, a 256 GB SSD hard drive (500+ GB is optimal), a 2TB external hard drive, webcam + mic, and consistent access to a reliable high-speed internet connection.

Employer demand for cyber security professionals continues to grow, with an estimated gap of over three million worldwide for cyber professionals as per the World Economic Forum (WEF) Global Risks Report 2022. Students who successfully complete this program may qualify for entry into Ontario college graduate certificate and university degree programs.

context:
The text discusses the Dental Assisting program offered at George Brown College, with concentrations at Levels I and II. Graduates of this program are eligible to take the National Dental Assisting Examining Board (NDAEB) examination to become certified Level II Dental Assistants in Ontario. They can find employment in various settings such as private dental practices, public health units, hospital dental clinics, dental industry, armed forces, and insurance companies. Graduates may apply to other dental programs at George Brown College but are not given priority admission. Certified dental assistants (Level I and II) can expand their skills with a certificate in dental office skills or dental treatment coordinator through the college's Continuing Education department.

Required courses for the Dental Assisting program include Dental Radiography I, Infection Prevention & Control for Dental Assisting, Introduction to the Dental Assisting Profession, Dental Sciences I, Dental Materials Theory I, Clinical Foundations Theory I, Oral Health & Prevention I, Clinical Foundations Practical I, Laboratory Procedures I, Business Office Skills, and Dental Radiography II. Additionally, students are required to take either English Skills or Communicating Across Contexts courses.

context:
The text provides information about a game design program offered by the college. Students in this program are required to assemble a portfolio or demo of their creative work before graduation to demonstrate their abilities and chosen area of specialization. Eligible students with approved portfolios can participate in external field placements during semester 3.

Graduates of the program may pursue careers in various roles within the game and digital media sector, including game designers, creative directors, level designers, producers, project managers, and more. They will have acquired necessary skills to be employed as game designers, creative directors, level designers, producers, project managers, etc.

The required courses for this program are listed semester-wise:

Semester 1:
- DESN 1101: Game Design Theory I (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1140: Narrative Design I (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1141: Game Psychology I (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1143: Advanced Level Design I (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1145: Game Management I (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1122: Design Documentation (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1101: Game Production Thesis I (Prerequisite: DESN 1101)

Semester 2:
- DESN 1111: Game Design Theory II (Prerequisite: DESN 1101)
- DESN 1149: Narrative Design II (Prerequisite: DESN 1140)
- DESN 1140: Game Psychology II (Prerequisite: DESN 1141)
- DESN 1144: Advanced Level Design II (Prerequisite: DESN 1143)
- DESN 1146: Game Management II (Prerequisite: DESN 1145)
- DESN 1147: Game Business (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1123: Game Production Thesis II (Prerequisite: DESN 1122)
- DESN 1122: General Education Electives (Prerequisite: None)

Semester 3:
- DESN 1072: Game Experiential Project (Prerequisite: None)
- DESN 1088: Studio Entrepreneurship (Prerequisite: None)

The graduate of the program will be able to design environment and characters using game design principles, read, analyze, and create game design documents, create environments, objects, and characters for integration within a video game, import game assets and levels into game engines, produce a 3D game, create and produce digital components, games, and documentation using various computer platforms, and demonstrate professional presentation and organizational skills.

context: The Early Childhood Education program at George Brown College is a two-year diploma program that teaches students how to support the holistic development of children from six weeks to 12 years of age in various settings. Domestic students starting in September 2023 and January 2024 may be eligible for a $2,000 tuition grant. The program consists of in-class learning and field placement to help students develop confidence in their skills. An accelerated option (C160) and fast-track option (C130) are also available for those who wish to enter the field quickly. Students will complete a seven-week field placement in each semester, providing opportunities to work with children of different age groups in various settings. The program is funded by the City of Toronto, the Region of Durham, the Region of Peel, the Province of Ontario, and the Government of Canada under the Canada-Ontario Early Childhood Workforce Agreement.

context:
The text is about an Early Childhood Education (ECE) program offered by George Brown College. The program provides opportunities for students to work with children of different age groups in various settings through field placements. George Brown operates Ontario's largest network of college-run lab school child care centres, serving over 1,100 children and their families each year. Graduates of the ECE program can find employment in various settings like child care centres, early years centres, parent resource centres, pediatric playrooms, special education settings, integrated kindergartens, therapeutic nursery programs, and in-home care. Successful completion of the program makes students eligible for entrance to Ontario's College of Early Childhood Educators as a Registered Early Childhood Educator. Students with a GPA of 2.5 or higher can apply to complete the bridge courses for entry into the third year of George Brown's Honours Bachelor of Early Childhood Leadership (Degree Completion) program, and their diploma will give them credit toward degree programs at other institutions.

Required courses in Semester 3 include: ECE 1069 - Health, Safety & Nutrition; ECE 2048 - Policy, Advocacy and Legislation; ECE 2049 - Inclusion in Early Childhood; ECE 1080 - Professional Development Workshop 2; ECE 2053 - Curriculum Theory; ECE 2056 - Creative Curriculum; and ECE 1183 - Integrated Sem.

context:
The text provides information about a program offered at George Brown College, specifically an electromechanical engineering program. Here are some key factual information extracted from the text:

- The program is designed for professional development and staying current in the field, including working as an individual and team member to complete tasks and projects.
- Students will design and analyze electromechanical systems using fluid mechanics principles.
- There are contributions to project management through planning, implementation, and evaluation of projects, as well as monitoring resources, timelines, and expenditures.
- Tuition and fees differ for domestic and international students, with listed amounts for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2022 and Fall 2023, respectively. Additional costs include safety shoes and glasses.
- The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
- Admission requirements include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to achieve required credits.
- The information in the text is subject to change without notice, and students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.

This advanced diploma program is focused on Building Automation and equips students with the technical skills required for installing, programming, adjusting, and maintaining building automation systems. Students will learn to collect data from sensors, actuators, and controllers and work with various building software platforms that interconnect different systems. The graduates of this program will have a diverse set of skills and abilities, including those needed for "green" careers.

The industry skills taught in the program include safety practices, HVAC/R processes, control loops and modes, working with blueprints and manufacturer's technical instructions, software usage, various BAS controls and systems, functions of network devices and protocols, and emerging green technologies.

Career options for graduates are available in various areas of the building industry. Some potential career paths include installation, maintenance, programming, and troubleshooting of HVAC/R and electrical systems using digital, analog, pneumatic, DCS, PLC, PAC, and SCADA controls and systems, as well as networking devices and protocols like Zigbee, WiFi, BAS/IP, and BACnet.

Emerging green technologies, such as solar, wind, and hydronic systems, are also covered in the program to prepare graduates for careers focused on energy efficiency, renewable energy, and sustainability.

- The program involves testing and troubleshooting electrical power systems under the supervision of a qualified person.
- Selecting and recommending power and control equipment, systems, and components to fulfill requirements.
- Applying systems analysis tools for sustainability and efficiency in managing power and control systems.

- Domestic tuition for first two semesters of programs starting Fall 2022: $6,115.00 (subject to change)
- International tuition for first two semesters of programs starting Fall 2023: $17,837.00 (subject to change)

context:
The college offers a Power Engineering Technology diploma program. In the first two years, students gain experience with power and control systems including electric motors, controls, PLCs, generators, transformers, electrical CAD, and electrical safety code. In the third year, students continue with advanced courses in electrical installations, power transmission and distribution, power quality, electrical protection and control, project management, automation systems, and control applications.

Graduating students perform technological functions related to power and control systems, energy, robotics and automation, manufacturing, processing, and computer industries. This work is primarily in support of research, technology installation, problem-solving, product development, and design at a recognized technologist level.

Students will complete two mandatory co-op semesters. The first co-op experience takes place between semesters 4 and 5, and the second co-op experience takes place between semesters 5 and 6.

Graduates will be in high demand for their cross-disciplinary skills in utilities, power generation and distribution, robotics and automation, computer industry, manufacturing industry, renewable energy industries.

The following are the required courses for the first and second semesters:

SEMESTER 1: Code Course Name EMNG 1001 Circuit Analysis EMNG 1004 Metrology MENG 1002 Engineering Drawing MENG 1087 Machining Fundamentals MENG 1088 Occupational Health and Safety GSSC 1027 Personal Finance MATH 1160 Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1 COMM 2000 Communicating Across Contexts

SEMESTER 2: Code Course Name ELCL 1047 Residential Prints and Electrical Safety Code 1 EMNG 1013 Electric Devices EMNG 1015 Motors and Controls EMNG 1020 Computers and Microprocessors EMNG 1021 CAD Electrical Circuits

context:
The college offers an Electromechanical Technician program that can be completed through online learning with interactive packages on a personal computer. The program consists of 24 courses (modules) which contain text, audio, animations, testing software, and simulation software. Enrollment is open throughout the year, and students can complete the modules at their own pace. The typical completion time is 34 weeks, but there are no time limits.

Prerequisites for enrollment include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma with general level credits or equivalent, or mature student status. Students who have completed the Electronics Technician program can receive advanced standing and apply credits toward other programs such as PLC Technician, PLC Technician II, Robotics Technician, and Automation Technician.

The program prepares students for careers in industrial maintenance, design and installation, technical services, technical sales, and industrial research and development. Students will learn to work with complex hydraulic, pneumatic, electrical, computer, programmable logic, and electronic controls. Required courses include "Introduction to Electronics," "Current, Voltage and Resistance," "Ohm’s Law, Power and Energy," "Series Circuits," "Parallel Circuits," "Series-Parallel Circuits," "DC Measuring Instruments," "Industrial Control Devices," "Magnetism," "DC Motors and Control Circuits," "Alternating Voltages and Currents," "AC Measuring Instruments," "Capacitance and Capacitors."

Courses should be taken in the following order: ELNC 9034, ELCL 9049, ELCL 9050, ELCL 9048, ELCL 9047, ELCL 9046, ELNC 9036, and ELNC 9053.

context:
The Fashion Techniques and Design program at the School of Fashion and Jewellery offers various related subject areas as electives, including fashion show development, portfolio development, draping, lingerie, men's pattern drafting, leather apparel, knitwear, and bridal and evening wear. Students are expected to have access to a personal laptop or desktop computer, printer, and reliable Internet for classes.

The program covers introductory methods to advanced concepts in the second year and provides opportunities for students to network with industry, participate in competitions, work on applied research projects, volunteer, and attend industry events. Extensive sewing experience and access to a sewing machine outside of campus facilities are required.

Graduates of this program may find career opportunities in various roles such as pattern drafting or construction, drafting and construction specifications, product development, assistant designers, technical designers, patternmakers, samplemakers, assistant apparel technicians, graders, marker makers, technical illustrators, product developers, stylists, design, trend and style consultants, and social media. Graduates with a minimum program GPA of 2.7 are eligible for admission to George Brown postgraduate programs.

The learning environment at the School of Fashion and Jewellery is diverse, and there are many extracurricular activities to take advantage of. The fashion show and portfolio event highlight successful student projects. The program requires students to study through the spring/summer semester and continue into the September academic year for a duration of 1.5 years for those starting in January. Both manual dexterity and good vision are assets for this program. Career opportunities range from small design studios to large manufacturing companies, and some graduates have also become entrepreneurs in design, sewing, and fashion service bureaus.

context:
The Game Development program at the college lasts for three years. In the first year, students take courses in drawing, 2D digital art, introduction to modelling and animation, interactive prototyping, studio lab, communicating across contexts, ludology and game history. Students can choose to specialize in game modelling or game animation starting from the second year.

In the second year, students specialized in game modelling take courses such as environment modelling I, game art and architecture I, level design I, texturing and shading I, studio lab III, general education elective. The same goes for the students specialized in game animation with a slight change in course names.

The required courses for year three include 3D sculpting I, organic modelling I, technical art for game engines 1, cinematics I and studio lab IV. Students are also required to take general education electives throughout their academic journey. The students have the opportunity to go for external field placements in semesters 5 and/or 6 if they have approved portfolios. Graduates of the program can find employment in the game industry at entry-level positions.

The Canadian video game industry contributed over $3 billion to the Canadian economy in 2015 and provided 20,400 full-time equivalent (FTE) jobs across the country. The industry is mainly concentrated in Quebec (29.4%), British Columbia (27.1%), and Ontario (22.9%).

The University of Gloucestershire offers a BSc (Honours) Computer Games Design program, to which graduates of Game Programming can apply starting from level 6.

The following is the curriculum plan for the Computer Games Design program in the academic year 2023-2024:

Semester 1:
- GAME 1001: Introduction to Programming
- GAME 1007: Game Fundamentals I
- GAME 1005: Game Production I
- GSSC 1027: Personal Finance
- MATH 1180: Math for Game Development
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Semester 2:
- GAME 1011: Advanced Programming
- GAME 1017: Game Fundamentals II
- GAME 3001: Artificial Intelligence
- GAME 1014: Game Production II
- MATH 1107: Linear Algebra and Geometry
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- GAME 2020: Game Production III
- GAME 3001: Data Structures & Algorithms
- GAME 2005: Game Physics
- GAME 2012: 3D Graphics Programming
- GAME 2013: Game Engines I
- GNED: General Education Elective (select one)

Semester 4:

- GAME 2031: Advanced Topics in Programming Languages
- GAME 3111: Advanced Graphics Programming
- GAME 3002: Physics Engines

context:
The Health Informatics graduate certificate program at George Brown College is designed for IT, health care or related professionals who aspire to enter into a health informatician/analyst role, or practitioners who wish to enhance their experience with formal education. The program provides students with skills and competencies in areas such as health care systems, ethical and policy implications of health information systems, problem identification and analysis, documentation and analysis of requirements, process and system modelling, project management, technical writing, leadership and management, and business and system analysis techniques.

The curriculum is applied in nature, with students engaged through case studies, industry projects, and practical work experience. Graduates will acquire knowledge, skills, and competencies relevant to professional certification programs in Health Informatics and Project Management. They will be able to formulate change strategies for implementing health information systems technologies (HIST) within a health-care setting, apply business and system analysis techniques to evaluate the effectiveness of HIST, design and prototype web and mobile health apps, integrate standards and requirements with appropriate HIST, design training and education for effective use of HIST, and configure all aspects of an EMR used by physicians in outpatient settings and multidisciplinary clinics.

The program partners with Arya Health, the maker of AryaEHR, a commercially available EMR, to provide students with hands-on experience.

question:
Program Description:
The Health Information Management (HIM) program at Seneca College is a 2-year Ontario College Diploma program, which provides students with the knowledge and skills required to manage health information in various healthcare settings. Students will learn about data management, information systems, privacy laws, and healthcare regulations, among other topics. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, with a strong emphasis on hands-on learning through laboratory sessions and field education placements in semesters 3 and 4.

Program Structure:
The HIM program consists of 12 full-time courses, delivered over four semesters. Students will attend classes at the Waterfront Campus in Toronto. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, with a strong emphasis on hands-on learning through laboratory sessions and field education placements in semesters 3 and 4.

Admission Requirements:
To be eligible for admission to the HIM program, applicants must meet the following requirements:

1. Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) or equivalent, with a minimum of six 12-unit Grade 12 C or U courses, including English 12C or U and Math 11M or U.
2. Achieve a minimum score of 75% in the CHIMA Health Information Management Admission Assessment.
3. Provide proof of immunization.

Program Delivery:
The HIM program is delivered in a full-time, on-campus format, with classes scheduled Monday to Friday. Students are required to attend classes and participate in laboratory sessions, simulations, and field education placements throughout the academic year. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, with a strong emphasis on hands-on learning.

Experiential Learning:
The HIM program includes two semesters of field education placements, which provide students with valuable work experience in healthcare settings. Students will apply the knowledge and skills they have learned in the classroom to real-world situations under the supervision of experienced professionals. The placements offer students an opportunity to gain practical experience in a variety of healthcare settings and develop essential professional competencies.

Accreditation:
The Health Information Management program at Seneca College is accredited by the Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA). Graduates of the program are eligible for membership with CHIMA and can pursue national certification as a Registered Health Information Administrator (RHIA) or a Certified Health Records Analyst (CRHA), depending on their chosen career path.

Career Opportunities:
Graduates of the HIM program may find employment opportunities in various healthcare settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, clinics, and government agencies. Some potential job titles include Health Information Manager, Health Records Administrator, Data Analyst, Privacy Officer, and Health Information Technician. Additionally, graduates with an HIM diploma can continue their education to pursue a Bachelor's or Master's degree in Health Information Management or related fields.

Additional Fees:
There are additional fees associated with the HIM program, including textbooks, lab supplies, and field education placement fees. Students should consult the Seneca College website for up-to-date information on these costs.

Further Information:
For more detailed information about the Health Information Management program at Seneca College, including application procedures, tuition fees, course descriptions, and program requirements, please visit the Seneca College website or contact the Program Coordinator directly.

Note: This document is intended to provide an overview of the HIM program at Seneca College and is subject to change without notice. Students are encouraged to consult the official Seneca College calendar for the most accurate and up-to-date information on the program.?

context:
The Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA) offers a certification program for Health Information Management practitioners. The curriculum covers various topics including biomedical sciences, health informatics, health record systems, medical classification systems and coding, data collection, statistical analysis and presentation, health-care legislation, and more.

Graduates of the program are eligible to write the Canadian Health Information Management Association national certification examination. The program requires students to bring their own laptop computer during the duration of the program.

Field placement is integrated throughout the second year of the program, with students visiting partner offices every Friday and completing a project related to health data during a three-week block placement. Field experiences can be conducted at various sites such as health-care facilities, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, health-related insurance companies, Ontario Hospital Association, and community care access centres. Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.

Career opportunities for Health Information Management graduates exist within the public and private sectors including acute care hospitals.
question:
Title: Health Information Management (HIM) Program at Seneca College: Overview, Curriculum, Field Placement, Certification, and Career Opportunities

Introduction:
Health Information Management (HIM) is a crucial aspect of the healthcare industry, dealing with the collection, analysis, protection, and communication of patient health information. The HIM program at Seneca College in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to excel in this field. In this article, we will explore the overview, curriculum, field placement, certification, and career opportunities for graduates of the Seneca College HIM program.

Overview:
The HIM program at Seneca College is a two-year diploma program designed to prepare students for careers in various health information management roles. The curriculum covers topics including health data systems, medical terminology, health record administration, statistical analysis, and health information technology. Students will also gain hands-on experience through field placements and internships.

Curriculum:
The Seneca College HIM program consists of the following courses:
1. Anatomy & Physiology for Health Professionals
2. Medical Terminology I & II
3. Health Records Administration I, II, & III
4. Data Collection and Management in Health Information Systems
5. Legal and Ethical Issues in Health Care
6. Health Informatics I & II
7. Health Information Technology
8. Health Statistical Analysis and Presentation
9. Research Methods for Health Professionals
10. Management of Health Information Systems
11. Field Placement I, II, & III

Field Placement:
Seneca College's HIM program includes a comprehensive field placement component. Students will participate in three distinct placements throughout their second year. The field experiences can be conducted at various sites such as health-care facilities, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, health-related insurance companies, Ontario Hospital Association, and community care access centres. Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.

Certification:
Graduates of the Seneca College HIM program are eligible to write the Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA) national certification examination. CHIMA is the leading professional association for Health Information Management practitioners in Canada. The certification process ensures that graduates have met the required educational standards and possess the essential skills and knowledge necessary for a successful career in HIM.

Career Opportunities:
The HIM field offers numerous opportunities for career growth within the public and private sectors. Some potential career paths include:
1. Health Information Technician/Specialist
2. Health Records Clerk/Coordinator
3. Health Data Analyst
4. Health Information Systems Manager
5. Health Information Security Officer
6. Clinical Documentation Improvement Specialist
7. Health Care Compliance Officer
8. Medical Coding and Billing Specialist
9. Health Information Privacy Officer

Conclusion:
The HIM program at Seneca College offers students a comprehensive educational experience, providing them with the necessary skills and knowledge to excel in this dynamic field. With its strong curriculum, hands-on field placements, CHIMA certification preparation, and diverse career opportunities, the Seneca College HIM program is an excellent choice for those seeking a rewarding career in health information management.?

question:
Title: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) - Field Placement Requirements

The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) program at XYZ University has certain health and placement requirements for students. These requirements are essential to ensure the safety and wellbeing of patients, clients, and students during clinical placements.

1. Health Requirements:
Students must meet specific health requirements before starting their field placements. These requirements include having up-to-date immunizations, a negative tuberculosis (TB) test result within the past year, and being free from any communicable diseases. Students should consult with their campus Health Services office to ensure they meet these requirements.

2. Police Vulnerable Sector Check:
Students are required to obtain a Police Vulnerable Sector Check for field or clinical placements in the program. The Police Vulnerable Sector Check must be renewed annually and covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons. The process typically takes two to three months but can take up to eight months. Students are responsible for paying the fees associated with these requirements and keeping the original copy of their Police Vulnerable Sector Check. International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Students who cannot provide a "clear" check may not be able to start their placement and therefore may be unable to complete the program.

3. Pre-placement:
The text mentions a Pre-placement website, but no link is provided. We recommend that students visit the pre-placement portal regularly for important updates and information related to their clinical placements.

4. COVID-19 Vaccination:
Public health recommends that students be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete the field placement component in the regularly scheduled time frame. This requirement may vary depending on the specific placement site's policies and local public health guidelines. Students should consult with their clinical placement sites regarding any COVID-19 vaccination requirements.

5. Application:
Domestic students should apply through the unspecified application method for clinical placements. International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.

For more information, please contact the School of Nursing at XYZ University.?

The program aims to prepare students to become practitioners and leaders in behavior analysis. It is an intensive on-site program focused on five areas of learning: behavioural science theories, special populations, psychology, research methods/statistics, ethics, professionalism, and leadership.

Advanced-entry options are available for students with a 3.0 GPA or higher, who have completed one of the following prerequisites: an approved Ontario college behavioral science technician diploma program, two years of George Brown’s Behavioural Science Technology advanced diploma (C116) program, or graduated from George Brown's Behaviour Science Technician (C146) diploma program. External applicants will be assessed for advanced standing on a case-by-case basis. As of July 2024, the profession of applied behavior analysis in Ontario will come under the jurisdiction of the newly expanded College of Psychologists and Behaves (sic).

question:
George Brown College provides an Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S303) degree program for eligible students. Eligibility is granted to students who have completed two years of the Behavioural Science Technology (C116) advanced diploma or graduated from the Behavioural Science Technician (C146) diploma program. The bridge semester occurs during spring/summer (semester 4).

The degree focuses on Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), which aims to modify behaviour in a positive manner for populations with various conditions such as Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), brain injury, dementia, developmental disabilities, addiction, and mental health disorders. The program is divided into three main components:

1. Behavioural assessment: Identifying the problematic behaviour through observations, interviews, and other relevant data sources.
2. Developing an effective plan based on the assessment results: Creating an individualized intervention plan tailored to the client's needs and goals.
3. Ongoing evaluation of components one and two: Regularly monitoring the progress of clients and making necessary adjustments to the intervention plan as needed.

The research component is a crucial aspect of the program, with students learning how to prepare an applied research proposal during semesters 5 and 6, followed by conducting the research in the Fall semester of their fourth year.?

Majors: Accounting (B322)

The George Brown College offers various programs in the field of commerce with a focus on financial services. Some of these programs include the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) degree, B322 Accounting program, and B302 Financial Planning program.

Graduates of the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) degree can find employment in various business sectors such as banks, financial institutions, government offices, and service organizations. Some of the potential job titles include financial services representative, associate financial planner, personal banker, and financial advisor.

The B322 Accounting program is accredited by Chartered Professional Accountants (CPA) of Ontario and prepares graduates for admission into the CPA Professional Education (PEP) program. The B302 Financial Planning program is approved by FP Canada and covers the core and advanced curriculum required to take the CFP examination.

Graduates of these programs may also wish to pursue additional credentials or certifications in the financial services sector such as Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP) through FP Canada, Canadian Securities Course (CSC) through the Canadian Securities Institute, and Life License Qualification Program (LLQP) through Oliver’s Learning or another approved provider.

Effective April 1, 2022, CFP Certification requires a minimum bachelor’s degree. For more information regarding the CPA and CFP designations, please visit their respective websites.

Program: Culinary Management
Institution: George Brown College
Objective: Develop strategies to achieve organizational objectives in various food service environments, manage partnerships and customer relationships, plan and execute contemporary cooking techniques, among other skills.

The Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) is an undergraduate degree program offered by George Brown College that combines culinary, food studies, commerce, and externship experiences. Students will gain knowledge and skills in eight key areas: culinary proficiency, culinary theory, accounting and finance, marketing and communications, human resources and risk management, specialized business, research, and general knowledge (liberal studies).

The program includes a unique and robust externship experience where students can work with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities. Students are encouraged to pursue self-directed industry work experience. This valuable work experience can be added to their resume.

After graduation, career options include food service employment areas such as director of operations in multi-unit food service, corporate/menu development chef, director of food service in retirement facilities and chains, executive chef, director of food & beverage in hospitality and tourism, corporate or regional chef, district manager, regional manager, and regional vice-president in contract food service management, and development chef or sales in food processors and brokers.
